title: 111_hr230
content: The Act may be cited as the "Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009". It includes provisions for affordable refinancing mortgages and new mortgages. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation will purchase and securitize qualified refinancing mortgages and new mortgages on single-family housing as per the Director's policies. Lenders can offer mortgages for purchase under this section, and the enterprise will determine eligibility. The enterprise will determine if mortgages are qualified under the Director's policies and make a commitment to purchase them if they meet the requirements. Lenders can receive advance commitments for qualified mortgages. The enterprise will establish a procedure for lenders to receive advance commitments for qualified mortgages. Qualified mortgages include qualified refinancing mortgages or qualified new mortgages. Qualified refinancing mortgages must meet specific requirements. The term "qualified refinancing mortgage" refers to a mortgage for a one to four-family dwelling that is the mortgagor's principal residence and is used for refinancing a principal loan amount. The qualified refinancing mortgage must be used to pay off all debt from an existing first mortgage on the same property, originated before January 1, 2008. The qualified refinancing mortgage must have an interest rate not exceeding 4.0 percent annually and a term to maturity of 30 to 40 years from the beginning of the mortgage amortization. The mortgage for refinancing must meet underwriting standards set by the Director and have all prepayment penalties and fees waived. The term "qualified new mortgage" refers to a mortgage that meets specific requirements, including being used to purchase the property it secures. The mortgage repayment is secured by the mortgage and used to purchase the property subject to the new mortgage. New mortgages must be originated after the enactment of this Act. Enterprises can establish exceptions to underwriting standards to purchase and securitize qualified refinancing mortgages. The enterprises can purchase and securitize qualified refinancing mortgages and new mortgages under specific requirements set by the Director. Each enterprise must set aside qualified mortgages and issue securities approved by the Secretary of the Treasury. Securities can be in the form of debt obligations or trust certificates. Securities issued under this subsection may be in the form of debt obligations or trust certificates of beneficial interest, with maturities and interest rates determined by the enterprise with approval from the Secretary. Securities issued by an enterprise under this subsection are exempt and deemed to be on par with securities guaranteed by the United States. Securities issued under this subsection, whether debt obligations or trust certificates, are guaranteed by the United States. Mortgages set aside must ensure timely payments on the securities. Each enterprise must include appropriate language in all issued securities. Each enterprise must include language in securities issued under this subsection, clearly stating that they are not guaranteed by the United States or any agency, and do not constitute a debt of the United States. The Federal Reserve will establish a credit facility to provide credit to the enterprises at comparable interest rates to securities issued. The Federal Reserve System will provide credit to enterprises at interest rates similar to Treasury securities. The enterprises are not required to purchase mortgages after December 31, 2010. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines the Director as the head of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, the Enterprise as the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, and the Secretary as the Secretary of the Treasury.
